quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Don't worry if you get it wrong‚Äîthat's how you learn!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: Your team has 15 items in progress simultaneously. Everyone is busy, but nothing is getting finished. The board shows: 2 items in 'To Do', 15 in 'In Progress', and 0 in 'Done'. Team members keep starting new work before finishing existing work. Lead time has increased from 5 days to 20 days.
quickScenarioChallenge.question: What's the PRIMARY Kanban/Lean principle being violated?

options.A: The team needs to work faster and add more people
options.B: Limit Work in Progress (WIP) to improve flow and reduce lead time
options.C: Add more columns to the board to track progress better
options.D: Create detailed timelines for each work item

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: B - Limit Work in Progress (WIP) to improve flow and reduce lead time

insights.explanation: Too much WIP creates bottlenecks, context switching, and delays. WIP limits force focus and completion.
insights.pmbokSupport: Kanban principle: Limit WIP to improve throughput and reduce cycle time

insights.explanation: Value comes from finished work, not started work. Optimize for flow, not busyness.
insights.pmbokSupport: Lean thinking: Stop starting, start finishing

insights.explanation: Less WIP = faster flow = shorter lead time from request to delivery
insights.pmbokSupport: Kanban metric: Lead time measures total time from request to delivery

insights.explanation: Pull new work only when capacity exists (WIP limit allows), don't push work
insights.pmbokSupport: Kanban principle: Pull system prevents overload and improves flow

trapSection.explanation: Options A, C, and D miss the core problem and would make things worse.

trapTable.violation: Adding people or pressure increases WIP and coordination overhead
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: Violates flow optimization and Little's Law (more WIP = longer lead time)

trapTable.violation: More columns don't address the WIP problem‚Äîthey hide it
Detailed timelines add overhead and don't address WIP overload
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: Predictive thinking in a flow-based system

patternRecognition.patternRule: When you see many items in progress but nothing finishing, the solution is WIP limits. When lead time increases, reduce WIP.

coreFramework.frameworkName: FLOW FAST Framework - Kanban & Lean Principles
coreFramework.frameworkIntro: Kanban and Lean focus on flow, not iterations. Here's what PMI expects you to know:

rows.action: Optimize for smooth flow of value, not resource utilization
Set WIP limits to force focus and improve throughput
rows.examKeywords: WIP limit, work in progress, queue limit, focus

rows.action: Reduce time from request to delivery; measure and improve
rows.examKeywords: lead time, cycle time, throughput, velocity

rows.action: Pull work when capacity exists, don't push work
Make work visible on Kanban board; transparency enables flow
Prioritize completing work over starting new work

step.name: Track Metrics (Lead Time, Cycle Time, Throughput)

rows.action: Use flow metrics to measure and improve predictability
rows.examKeywords: metrics, lead time, cycle time, cumulative flow

coreFramework.additionalContent:
üí° Kanban vs Scrum

Scrum: Fixed-length iterations (Sprints), defined roles, prescribed events

Kanban: Continuous flow, no iterations, no prescribed roles, evolutionary change

Both: Agile, empirical, incremental delivery, visual boards

7 Lean Wastes (TIMWOOD): Transportation, Inventory, Motion, Waiting, Overproduction, Over-processing, Defects

pmbokConnection.quote: Kanban is a strategy for optimizing flow. Lean thinking focuses on eliminating waste and maximizing value.

steps: T - Track Metrics (lead time, cycle time)

visualReferenceCard.quickReference: Kanban optimizes flow through WIP limits and pull. Lean eliminates waste. Both focus on continuous delivery without fixed iterations.
visualReferenceCard.goldenRule: When work piles up, LIMIT WIP. When lead time increases, REDUCE WIP. More WIP = longer lead time (Little's Law).
visualReferenceCard.examTip: Exam tests: WIP limits, pull vs push, lead time vs cycle time, 7 wastes (TIMWOOD), and Kanban vs Scrum differences.
visualReferenceCard.pmbokPrinciple: Lean: Eliminate waste, optimize flow. Kanban: Visualize, limit WIP, manage flow.

secondScenario.title: Apply Kanban & Lean Principles
secondScenario.intro: Now that you know the framework, let's apply it to a new situation.
secondScenario.scenarioStory: Your team's Kanban board shows: To Do (20 items), In Progress (8 items with WIP limit of 5), Testing (12 items with WIP limit of 3), Done (2 items). Work is accumulating in Testing. The team wants to start more items from To Do because 'developers are idle.'
secondScenario.question: What should the team do according to Kanban principles?

options.A: Start more items from To Do since developers have capacity
options.B: Help finish Testing items (swarm the bottleneck), don't start new work
options.C: Increase WIP limits to allow more work in each column
options.D: Add more testers to handle the Testing queue

quotes.text: Kanban is a strategy for optimizing the flow of value through a process that uses a visual, pull-based system. The goal is to limit the amount of work in progress (WIP) to balance demand against the throughput of the delivery team.
quotes.author: PMI

quotes.text: Remember Little's Law: Lead Time = Work in Progress / Throughput. To reduce lead time, either reduce WIP or increase throughput. But you can't increase throughput by adding more WIP‚Äîthat's the trap! Reduce WIP first.
quotes.author: PMP Instructor Insight

fieldInsights.title: Real-World Application
fieldInsights.insight: Many teams adopt a Kanban board but ignore WIP limits. That's just a fancy to-do list, not Kanban. The power of Kanban comes from WIP limits creating focus, exposing bottlenecks, and forcing continuous improvement.

fieldInsights.title: Exam Strategy
fieldInsights.insight: When you see a flow/Kanban question, look for: Are WIP limits defined? Is work accumulating somewhere (bottleneck)? Is the team starting too much? The answer usually involves limiting WIP, swarming bottlenecks, and optimizing flow.

memoryPalace.title: üèîÔ∏è Memory Palace: The Flow River Mountain
memoryPalace.intro: Anchor Kanban and Lean with this vivid mountain climbing story. As you read, visualize each scene:

story.title: The River of Work
story.narrative: You're climbing a mountain with a river running down it. The river represents work flowing from top (To Do) to bottom (Done). You must manage the flow.

scenes.description: You stand by the river and watch the FLOW of water. Some sections flow smoothly; others are clogged with debris (bottlenecks). Your job: optimize flow, not force more water in.
You see dam gates at each section of the river with numbers: '3 items max,' '5 items max.' These WIP LIMITS control how much can flow through each section. No cheating‚Äîthe gates are locked!
A stopwatch tracks how long each item takes from the top of the mountain (request) to the bottom (delivered). LEAD TIME. You measure it constantly to improve.
Along the riverbank, you see 7 trash bins labeled TIMWOOD: Transportation, Inventory, Motion, Waiting, Overproduction, Over-processing, Defects. You throw away anything that doesn't add value.
A PULL rope system: when work finishes at the bottom, it pulls the next item from upstream. Work is PULLED when capacity exists, never PUSHED.
The river is crystal clear‚Äîyou can see EVERY item flowing through. The KANBAN BOARD makes all work visible. No hidden work, no surprises.
A sign at the top reads: 'FINISH what's flowing before adding more!' You see climbers helping items reach the DONE pool at the bottom, rather than tossing new items in at the top.
A dashboard displays: Lead Time (15 days ‚Üì), Cycle Time (8 days ‚Üì), Throughput (5 items/week ‚Üë). You track these METRICS to measure and improve flow.

story.moral: The river flows best with WIP limits, pull systems, and waste elimination. Too much work clogs the river. Optimize flow, not busyness.

memoryPalace.selfTest: Close your eyes and visualize the Flow River. Can you recall the 8 FLOW FAST principles using the river story?
